     the itunes downloads / spotify streams / the other music stores, etc. should have the highest quality ones available

6.29.18  2:51 am   hey bill, i really want to make music but i have no idea where or how to start. i don't have any sort of instrument, no microphone, no audio program or knowledge on how to use it, i
can't read music, and my voice isn't even that good and i don't know how to improve it. but i feel like there is stuff i need to write and simple poetry isn't enough, i need to create it as music. but i just don't know how to start.. can you give any advice 

     it's magnetic. if you need someone else to tell you how to find it, then it might not be right for you. but if it is right for you it should be screaming at you very loudly and it will be pretty easy to track it down ..... it's everywhere

6.29.18  1:28 am   I've taken theory III and I still don't understand tritone substitution can you explain it to me

     imagine you are in a song, minding your own business, ... let's say the song is in the key of C ... and let's say there is a G7 chord. .. following me so far? the G7 chord has notes b and f in the mid-range, that's the important notes of the chord. (that's a tritone interval but that's not why it's called substitution, we haven't done the substitution yet, that will be in the bass.) so let's say you play b and f notes (at the same time) in the middle range, and the bass plays G (note.) that pretty much makes a G7 chord. ok now the bass player plays a prank and plays Db (note) instead, while the piano still plays the b+f notes. pow, now it's a Db7 chord

6.28.18  5:20 pm   hey bill, i have always been interested in music & wanted to make/play it. i love listening to it & i find your music really cool & inspiring. you talk a lot about just starting if you want to make music/something creative & just doing it in your answers. anyways, i want to start making music but i don't have any knowledge in music theory beyond very simple concepts from elementary school which i have mostly forgotten, & i don't really want to learn music theory in a very systematic way (i.e. how it seems to be typically taught in classes, by starting with very basic things that are kind of boring and just playing a bunch of classical songs). do you think can you learn & create music just by listening to it?

     yes

      is it important to know all the different parts of music (notes, chords, riffs, mixing, bass, the stuff you mention) or can you just do it by ear?

     if you're not doing music by ear it pretty much won't work

      i feel like i can sort of make up lyrics just by singing what i think of but i don't know how to make music to go with it, or making music in general. like i don't really know how to play any instruments or work with sounds and stuff.

     if you listen you will find out

     i think i should just start but i don't know. whenever i try to sit down & do something it feels very intimidating, & i don't know how to begin or what to do. thanks for your time.

     just try to have a good time ..... there are many many ways to have a good time, in music and other wise

6.28.18  1:10 pm   So, say you have a note that goes til the end of a beat, and then a note right at the top of the next beat (like a quarter note on beat 1, then a quarter note on beat 2).. Wouldn't that mean that, technically, that first note shouldn't be released until the exact same moment that the 2nd note is played? If you have to lift up from the 1st note to play the 2nd note, then wouldn't you be cutting the duration of the the quarter note slightly short just for that little tiny moment between the notes? Is that little moment so negligible that I shouldn't even think about that? And then, the natural sustain of the instrument/sound could effect that as well? Like sometimes it would be impossible to sustain the first note until the exact moment the 2nd note is played (like if you're playing 2 fretted notes on the same string of a guitar or bass that are farther apart than what you can reach without moving your hand)... If I want to have 2 instruments play the same line, would it be more accurate to think of that 1st quarter note as, like a dotted eighth note and a sixteenth rest (or maybe even an eighth note, dotted sixteenth and a 32nd rest) so that the release of the notes happen at the exact same time? I've never really thought about this before, but now that I am thinking about it, I'm confusing myself. When I read rhythmic notation I'm usually thinking primarily about where the notes hit, more so than the duration of each note. Like if I had 4 quarter notes, I'd now that each note should be played on the beat, but I'd probably play the 4 quarter notes no different than then if it were written as alternating dotted eighth notes and sixteenth rests (unless it's a really slow tempo) Obviously for something like a quarter note and a quarter rest, I wouldn't play the same way as a half note.. but when you get down to those little itty bitty tiny moments in between the notes, do those essentially not matter rhythmically? 

     if no articulation is written, i think it might be assumed that there is at least a little bit of space before the next note

6.28.18  6:18 am   hello bill. i want to make music as a living. i went to music school (but i never finished). but when i tried to make music professionally i couldn't survive financially and had to get a day job. but the day job eats up my schedule and have very little time to practice, find gigs or perform.

     i think you only need to have time for 1 of those things, and i think you have time for it. find gigs. then once you find them, go to them. and that's your practice too, gigs is the best practice anyway

      now i'm at work, in the office, thinking about quitting all together, cause i feel like even though i want to pursue music as a career, i can never be good enough to be financially stable. Should i just quit?
